posts.cooked:
Hello,

Our team is attempting to drive our robot using velocity control and later position control. The thing is I cannot figure out how to do it.

I’ve looked up videos and guides and they all mention PID(F) control. I figured out today how to get starting KP and KD values using the System Identification tool (though I think the numbers are incorrect). But I’m not sure how to transfer what I have to code.

I believe I can set velocity using motor.set(ControlMode.Velocity, velocity) Then I can pick a maximum velocity and set our joystick maximum to that value and have a linear equation in between but how does that connect to PID(F)?

I feel like I’m missing something obvious here since no one is mentioning it.

Please help,

posts.name: NewtonCrosby
posts.cooked:
ebrooks:

Hello,

Our team is attempting to drive our robot using velocity control and later position control. The thing is I cannot figure out how to do it.

…

What is the problem you’re trying to solve with a velocity and positional PID rather than output motor control (e.g. ControlMode.PercentOutput)?

I’m massively in favor of teams trying to stretch and learn, but I’d also counsel teams to ensure they know what problem they are attempting to solve when trying something ambitious.

For example, I don’t think that teams should try to run 1678 or 254’s custom scheduling libraries to control their robot.  There are a few teams that could improve their performance from what WPILib provides, but in the end, those that are capable enough to achieve those benefits know enough to do it without help.

Secondary to that, if you’ve implemented something by following CTRE ’s documentation and it’s not working post your code and we can help see what’s going on and get you over the hump.

posts.cooked:
We would eventually like to try trajectory tracing and this is one of the steps necessary in doing that.

All I have found on CTR is this link https://docs.ctre-phoenix.com/en/stable/ch16_ClosedLoop.html which talks about it but doesn’t say how to do it.

I’m not trying to go outside of WPILib I watched this video https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wqJ4tY0u6IQ and they seemed able to do it but again I feel like I’m missing something in going from what they have to using a joystick.
I’ve seen those. What I seem to be missing is how to do those affect the velocity of the robot?

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: A controller affects the velocity of the robot by controlling the voltage sent to the motors.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.custom_user_title: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.cooked:
But how do you connect the Feedforward to the motors?

Say I have frontLeft as a motor and feedForward as the simple feed forward

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: This is covered in the feedforward control article at the very bottom, under “Using Feedforward to Control Mechanisms.”

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.custom_user_title: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.cooked: Thank you I feel like an idiot and will try that.

I assume you just switch that to

leftMotor.set(ControMode.Velocity, feedforward.calculate(leftVelocity));

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
No.  The feedforward calculates a voltage from a velocity; its return value is a voltage.  For pure feedforward (open-loop) control, you send that voltage to the motors.  To gain additional control fidelity, you can add to the open-loop output the results of a feedback calculation (such as PID), which will also be a voltage.

You can send the feedforward value to the CTRE motor controllers through their arbitraryFeedForward parameter if you want to use it in conjunction with on-controller feedback loops - be aware, though, that the scaling there is not in volts but instead covers [-1,1] .

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.custom_user_title: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.cooked:
Ok so it would be

leftMotor.set(ControMode.PercentOutput, feedforward.calculate(leftVelocity));

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: Almost!  You need to convert from a voltage to a percent output - to do this, divide by the current battery voltage (or, if you have voltage compensation enabled on your motor controller, by the nominal battery voltage that you told to the motor controller).
